SENT.plain: PURPOSE: Observational studies on the association between white meat (including fish and poultry) intake and the risk of colorectal adenoma (CRA), the precursor of colorectal cancer, have reported mixed results
To provide a quantitative assessment of this association, we summarized the evidence from observational studies
METHODS: Relevant studies published on or before April 30, 2012 were identified from MEDLINE and EMBASE
Summary effect size estimates with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated with a random-effects model
Between-study heterogeneity was assessed using the Cochran Q and I(2) statistics
RESULTS: A total of 23 publications from 21 independent studies (16 case-control and 5 cohort studies) were included in this meta-analysis

Based on high versus low analysis, the summary effect size estimate of CRA was 0.96 (95% CI, 0.84-1.09) for white meat intake, 0.98 (95% CI, 0.80-1.19) for fish intake, and 0.98 (95% CI, 0.80-1.18) for poultry intake

Subgroup analyses revealed that the null associations of CRA with intake of white meat (fish/poultry) were independent of geographic locations, study design, type of food frequency questionnaire, number of cases, and adjustments for confounders, such as body mass index, use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, dietary energy intake, smoking, and physical activity
CONCLUSIONS: Intake of white meat (fish/poultry) is not associated with the risk of CRA
